pros: Great faculty and staff members
cons: I have no cons for this job

review_title: POOR SALARY THAT IS NOT COMPETITIVE IN 2023
pros: Great Hours Earn a lot of days off as a full time employee Free tuition for your family if they attend the college (only full-time employees) Tuition reimbursement for employees
cons: Poor starting salary for people who have bachelor's and master's degrees. Yearly increases are not relevant to today's economy. They want BMW service for Ford pay, Health Benefits premium is high. A lot of red tape, egos, and personal biases get in the way of the college's potential to make an impact in the community.

review_title: No room for growth and poor base pay for a bachelors and masters degree
pros: Relaxed environment and Fridays off from mid May to Mid August
cons: Pay is low, Benefits are high, no room for growth unless you are favored, too much red tape.

pros: It was a nice facility.
cons: The pay does not compare to work assigned.

pros: flexible and very great people
cons: none none none none none

review_title: Camden County College is an excellent place to work.
pros: The college provides an atmosphere of  congeniality, safety and assistance to those in need.P
cons: Parking can become a challenge during peak times of day and evening.

pros: Overtime is possible, sick pay, vacation pay
cons: Only able to get part time

pros: Diverse work environment and great benefits, once full time.
cons: They are slow to promote from within, unless you're super well liked.

pros: the people were wonderful to work with, the students were fun, and everyone seemed to care deeply about each other.
cons: limited pay, but they supported you in other ways

review_title: Great Place to Begin Teaching Career
pros: Autonomy with developing coursework and good student engagement, depending on the subject. Most students are eager to learn and many are hard-workers. The population includes many older students who have returned to college after many years and many international students who value education. If you are teaching an intensive subject such as English, you can really make a difference in the students' abilities to communicate well. All must pass a departmental exam and skills do rise considerably. A master's degree is required to teach at this level, although substantial experience can be substituted in some disciplines. The campus is quite nice and the facilities are very modern in many aspects. The affiliation with Rutgers has also improved campus environment. Large congregating areas in student center, a lot of open space and green areas where students play ball or frisbee,  and a dedicated student services building make the college feel more like a community.
cons: The pay is far less than at a 4-year university and there is no office space for adjuncts to hold office hours. Classes can be cancelled at the last minute due to low enrollment.   Enrollment is down and some have been laid off as the college restructures. Tenured professors can be burnt out and there is a strong bias against the lowly adjunct ---- even though adjuncts are doing all the heavy lifting.  This can create two kinds of adjuncts: those who are there to really teach and who put in all the time and effort that takes, and those who do the bear minimum for students, and who   run from job to job due to the low pay.

pros: I do not have any
cons: Not any downside just okay

job_title: Adjunct English Teacher in Blackwood, NJ
pros: Students were great. Length of classes were good. Pay is higher than other schools.
cons: Adjuncts are treated poorly here. Hands down this is the worst college to work if you are an adjunct. I am in the English department and it could be different in other departments..but I always felt alone. I never knew what was going on with paper work, course changes, and classes. I once did not get classes my second semester and if was because a form got lost in the mail. When I contacted abou classes I was told the forms were mailed out and I should have contacted sooner. How was I supposed to do that if it was my first semester and there is not communication? I did get a class but it was given to me last minute. I am telling you..they don't care or check up on you. I could have sat in the class and showed movies to my students every class and no one would have known. No check up, no observation, and no emails. I felt so alone at this school.

review_title: Great students, not so great management
pros: I enjoyed teaching at Camden County College. The students are great and the campuses are convenient. They were loyal in hiring and prompt with payment.
cons: Administration and management are non existent. I didn't even know how to get my class list on the first day of my classes. No one had told me about webadvisor, about where or how to make copies. Since the class had a departmental wide final, I always felt like I was teaching toward a test and there was a strong disparage between campuses and test results forcing me to conclude that there was class discrimination at the school. Plus, they adjunct pay at CCC is the worst I have ever experienced.

review_title: Senior Management needs to recognize the many extra efforts of staff
pros: For full time employees, the administration is quite supportive of academic faculty.  Also, for Full time employees, the College is a good employer, especially regarding health care and other benefits.
cons: Camden County College does little to recognize those employees who extend themselves to support the students.  Additionally, the College, generally, treats the adjunct faculty as "second rate" employees.

review_title: Stagnant growth opportunities and undervalued employees
pros:
Great Benefits, minus the outrageous union dues paid to a union that does very little.
Opportunity to develop great experience in the higher education field.
Non-Management employees have great chemistry
cons:
Employees are undervalued especially in salary.
Management is not very professional.
The college is not moving fast enough technologically and will soon find themselves paying for their inability to keep up with advanced technology.

review_title: I teach Composition I and II as an Adjunct.  On average, I receive 2-3 classes per semester.
pros: Students are wonderful for the most part, classrooms are very tech-enhanced.
cons: Very difficult to for me to get classes on the same campus.  This semester I am teaching 3 classes on 2 different campuses, and I am scheduled to teach 2 classes next semester on 2 different campuses.  There is also very little recognition for Adjunct Professors by the administration.  I have received more encouraging words from my students, academic advising and disability services than the chair of the department or any other administration personnel.

pros:
Some students genuinely care about their coursework, and will be cordial and thankful to you for helping them.

Freedom. When you are teaching, it is as if you are your own boss, as long as you follow college policy and accreditation standards.

Many colleagues are friendly and offer helpful ideas for teaching and will share in your frustrations.

The cafeteria food is good. I am especially grateful to one of the employees who went out of his way to give me fresh food.
cons:
Attendance is way down, and the college is responding by hiring fewer full-time teachers. As a result, adjuncts are expected to do more than they ever have before, and have increased responsibilities/expectations. There are very little opportunities to advance to full-time faculty.

Many students are disrespectful even if you go the extra mile. One student told me I am 'old as ****' despite being nowhere near my senior years. Another blamed me for allegedly not doing my job as a teacher just days into the semester after he came up short on handing in the work he promised me he'd do (all he had to do was follow straightforward directions out of a book). Students will sometimes check off on feedback surveys that they don't think you care about them, even if you continuously go the extra mile to help them and do it with a smile. There are some good students, but experiences like these can truly sour the teaching experience. Do your best not to take it personally, if you choose to make this your long-term profession.

Campus security behavior can be appalling (although other officers are polite/professional). An officer grabbed me aggressively without making an effort to otherwise get my attention. I turned around to give him a yell back, and I ended up damaging a pair of headphones that I personally valued. Another officer endlessly rambled at me after I politely asked him to unlock a door so I could retrieve my USB drive.

The college releases shaming lists college-wide, of professors who do not meet deadlines for tasks such as syllabus submission.

pros: CCC is a very pleasant overall environment on a nice traditional campus.  As an adjunct, you are left alone, but if you need help, there are other adjuncts and staff willing to share their experiences.  The facilities at all three locations are clean and safe.
cons: Salary for adjuncts and contractors are low.  You dont know if you will have work from semester to semester. You can not earn a living as an adjunct.

review_title: Nepotism is the key to your success
job_title: Public Safety Officer in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: Decent compensation plan. You pay into the state pension plan, and you get free education as a college employee. Paid holidays off.
cons: Most of your colleagues are there because they're married to someone, related to someone, a child of someone, or fellating someone who works for the college or the county, meaning they can do whatever they please and face little to no repercussions.

review_title: An exciting, nurturing college administration where I learned a great deal and made good friends and personal contacts.
job_title: English, ESL, and History Tutor in Camden, NJ
pros: The educational field offers great personal growth, a challenging, ever changing work environment, and the opportunity top shape tomorrow's leaders.
cons: At times, it was working here was disappointing because great ideas of improvement are lost by the shuffle of a bloated senior administration.

review_title: Great college, and efficient workstudy environment.
pros: Flexible scheduling around classes. Compensation is higher then minimum wage. Great teamwork and support from advisers and supervisors.
cons: Limit to how much you can make per semester.

pros: Camden County provides a great resource to the community and it is nice to work at an instituion that strives to afford a good education to its students.
cons: Pretty stagnant. Most employees are lifers.

job_title: Adjunct Professor/Writing Tutor in Philadelphia, PA
pros: Fairly easy to communicate with superiors and with other departments regarding the success of students.
cons: Very low pay for the class size. Classes are often at capacity at beginning of semester. Very little offered in terms of sick leave or time off.

review_title: As a non-traditional student returning to studies at Camden County College, I was privileged to secure a work-study job.

pros: Forward thinking, Career Coaching, Educational
cons: No cons faced in this position

cons: Cronyism.  Weak union.  Enrollment is dropping.
